nd safety of its employees and the public.  The design, maintenance and operation of the facility are carried out in conformance with this policy to provide a safe operation and to prevent exposures of our employees and nearby neighbors to ammonia.  Management at the Hooker's Point Ammonia Terminal is responsible for the development and implementation of programs and procedures to ensure conformance with this philosophy.  The programs and procedures are continually reviewed and updated, and the facility is periodically audited to assure compliance. 

Tampa Port Services personnel are also trained in key aspects of emergency response.  The facility's Emergency Response Plan is based on OSHA's emergency response standard, 29 CFR 1910.120(q). The plan includes procedures for the notification of local fire and emergency response authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.  The facility is linked to a community alarm that provides emergency notification to nearby neighbors.  In addition, emergency preparedness is assured by:  Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) trained operators and supervisory personnel; emergency response drills with local emergency responders; ammonia sensors located at critical locations in the process area and along the facility perimeter; continuous computer monitoring of ammonia sensor readings and weather conditions; and water spray systems for ammonia vapor suppression.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps:

The Hooker's Point Ammonia Terminal is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  As recognized by EPA, the PSM standard forms the basis for the agency's RMP prevention program component.  The primary purpose of this facility's PSM program is to safeguard employees and nearby neighbors from exposure to ammonia by providing assistance in evaluating and updating the facility's process and mechanical safety procedures and programs.

Executive Summary 

Tampa Port Services, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of The Mosaic Company, owns and operates the Hooker's Point Ammonia Terminal.   In this Tampa Port Services distribution facility, we handle anhydrous ammonia, which is considered hazardous by EPA. The same properties that make anhydrous ammonia valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling anhydrous ammonia to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our employees and site workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations, and we are committed to conducting business and operating our facilities in a manner designed to protect the environment, and the health and safety of our employees, and our neighbors around the Ammonia Terminal.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance:

The Hooker's Point Ammonia Terminal serves as a vital link in supplying ammonia to its own
manufacturing facilities and other customers. Hooker's Point receives refrigerated anhydrous
ammonia from ships at the Port of Tampa's unloading dock. Ammonia is pumped from the ship to a low-pressure storage tank where the ammonia is refrigerated and stored at -28 °F. Truck loading facilities are on site to load ammonia from the storage tank for transfer to Mosaic's manufacturing facility and other customers. Hooker's Point may also transfer ammonia via a privately owned pipeline for delivery to Mosaic facilities. The only substance regulated under EPA's RMP requirements at the facility is ammonia.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Polices:

Hooker's Point has an extensive safety program to ensure compliance with all applicable local, state and federal rules and regulations.
